title: Sydney auction in Kingsford sees unassuming red-brick home sell for more than $7million
text:
An unassuming red-brick home sold in Sydney for more than $7million this weekend.

The sale is an indication property prices are on the climb again after a lull in the housing market.

While on the surface the single-storey property appears rather mundane - there's some rather large reasons why it has sold for so much.

The combined size of the land - which has a second home and two parking spaces - is a massive 1347 square metres - which is three times the size of the average block in Sydney.

The home is also in Kingsford, in Sydney's expensive eastern suburbs, next door to the University of NSW, Prince of Wales Hospital, Sydney Airport and the area's beaches and waterways. It's also just 10km from the centre of the city.

An unassuming red-brick home sold in Sydney for more than $7million this weekend

To make the home even more valuable, zoning recently changed to R3 - meaning its new owner will be able to build a substantial apartment block on the land.

WHAT DOES R3 ZONING MEAN? Zone R3 is a zone where multi dwelling housing is appropriate and encouraged. Multi dwelling housing can take the form of townhouses or villas, or a more community focused approach such as a childcare facility. It is normally reserved for 'medium density' residential areas.

The R3 zoning also means a bed and breakfast, childcare centre, community centre or hostels is approved for the site.

The value of the land and its development potential was why it sold at auction on the weekend for well above the average for the suburb.

It sold for a staggering $7.35 million - almost four times Kingsford's average price of $2 million.

Over 2000 other homes were also up for auction across the nation last weekend, up from 1324 the week prior.

CoreLogic data shows a steady improvement in clearance rates of homes this quarter.

More than 70 per cent of properties that hit the market from July-September were sold.
description: The sale is an indication property prices are on the climb again after a lull in the housing market.
authors: Brittany Chain For Daily Mail Australia
